Award.AbstractNarration:
Rational Attention and Adaptive Coding are two theories, developed in very different disciplines that try to explain very similar phenomena. Rational Attention is crucial in explaining important factors in the economic life of a country: for instance, in explaining how people respond to changes in prices, and why and how monetary policy is effective. Rational Attention is currently based on an ad hoc, ultimately weak and unsatisfactory theory of human decision making. Thus, we may be relying on a faulty theory to formulate essential policy decisions like monetary policy. Our proposal wants to provide a sound basis to the theory explaining what people pay attention to. To do so, it will apply to economic decision making the theory of Adaptive Coding, developed in Neuroscience, which explains how the brain adjusts to the environment to maximize the perception accuracy. For example, when one goes from a very bright outside into a dark room, his retina and brain adapts to the new intensity.
Rational Attention and Adaptive Coding pose a puzzle. The adaptation to the environment has the functional reason of using optimally information processing, but the adjustment introduces the possibility that environment biases choice. Three questions are the core of our proposed research: 1.What is the trade- off between the improvement in decision making and the bias? 2. If a bias is introduced, how is it corrected? 3. If correction requires time, what is the speed of the correcting mechanism? Our proposal will provide answers to the three questions, using a new and transformative method in the analysis of economic decision making, aimed at producing a fully mechanistic model of choice. In a mechanistic model there is a one-to-one correspondence between the variables in the model and the variables we measure in experimental analysis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
What is adaptive coding?

When individuals (animal or human) make choices, they face very different environments. In some environments, options available are rich, in others, they are scarcer. In some environments, goods of one type (say food) are more plentiful while those of another type (say shelter) are less. In deciding between two options that are available, animals respond in their judgment by adapting the system that evaluates rewards to these different circumstances. This happens in the same way in which our visual system adapts to different amounts of light: when the light is too bright, we adjust by reducing the sensitivity. When the light is dim, we adjust by increasing the sensitivity to the light stimulus. This is adaptive coding: the adjustment of our perceptual and reward-evaluating system to different circumstances in the environment. 


Why adaptive coding is a puzzle
Is has been known for a while that this adaptation has a precise neural bases: the neurons devoted to the evaluation of a type of goods (say, orange juice, for a monkey) respond more strongly to the same amount when that amount is large compared to the average available in the environment than they do when that same amount is small compared to the average. This adaptation, however, is puzzling: if the neural coding of a same amount of a good depends on the environment, we might (when we choose) seem to make the evaluation of an option depend on features of the environment rather than on the intrinsic worth of that good. In visual perception the same phenomenon occurs, under the suggestive name of coding catastrophe. So the question is: is adaptive coding fulfilling a function, or rather introducing a bias? In some branches of Economics the answer that it is a bias has been widely accepted, and has taken researchers to the conclusion that all our choices are hopelessly biased. We are not convinced. 

An experimental observation
The first fact we clarify is, in experiments done with monkeys, that adaptive coding does not imply behavioral biases. This is illustrated in the attached figure, which shows how the frequency of choice of two goods varies when we change the environment. In this experimental setup, it is known that neurons coding the value of the reward exhibit adaptive coding. Therefore, if adaptive coding is associated with a bias, the points would scatter along two different lines, one for each of the two types of environment. In fact, they do not, as one can easily see. So why do we see adaptive coding? 

Our method
We pose a formal question, translate it into a mathematical problem, find the answer, and check it with the data. The formal question is this: suppose you are an engineer that is given the constraint provided by the neural structure, and is asked to solve the problem of whether to adjust or not to the environment. Your task is the maximization of the gain in each environment. Would you choose to use the adaptive coding, and if so how, precisely? We translate this question into a precise mathematical maximization problem subject to constraints, and find the solution. 

Our results
The solution describes precisely the amount of adaptation that is optimal. We then compare it with the data, and find a remarkably good fit. We also find that the reason that makes adaptive coding optimal is that neurons communicate in a very special way: they fire according to a Poisson process. A very special property of this stochastic process (namely, that the mean of the firing rate is equal to its variance) is the only reason that adaptive coding is effective in communicating the value of the options. The bias does not arise, at least not in a stable way (it may arise for short period of transitions from one environment to another) because another component, synaptic efficacy, is added to the mechanism.
